title-group.article-title: Composite anterolateral thigh perforator flaps in the management of complex hand injuries

author-notes.corresp: Moustafa Meky, 174Z Hadek Al-haram, Giza, Cairo, Egypt. Email: mostafamikki@hotmail.com

permissions.copyright-holder: The British Society for Surgery of the Hand

abstract.p: The anterolateral thigh (ALT) fasciocutaneous flap has been well described for hand skin cover, however its use in its composite (multiple tissue) form incorporating bone, muscle and/or fascia has been less well described. We report the usefulness of the composite ALT flap in six complex hand trauma cases, four male and two female (age range 14–46 years). The palm of the hand was affected by injury in three cases, the dorsum in two cases, and the radial side in one case. The first web formed part of the injury in three cases. There was variable involvement of the tendons, nerves and bones. Fascia lata was included in the flap to provide a gliding surface in four cases, part of the vastus lateralis muscle was included to obliterate dead space in two cases and to create a first web in one case, and a bone block from the iliac crest was included to reconstruct the lost metacarpals in one case. All flaps survived with minimal complications. This work shows that the anterolateral thigh composite flap is a reliable option when multiple tissue types are required in hand reconstruction.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Free flaps can be designed in a composite form to provide vascularized tissue components like tendons, muscle, fascia, bone and nerves in addition to skin coverage (Caroli et al., 1993; Hou and Liu, 1993; Momeni and Stark, 2006; Posch et al., 2005). Using these composite flaps in complex hand injuries may reduce the stages of reconstruction, allow early rehabilitation, and perhaps improve outcome.

The ALT flap has been used in hand reconstruction as a skin flap or as a composite flap (Adani et al., 2006; Hsu et al., 2009; Javaid and Cormak, 2003; Kimura et al., 2008; Muneuchi et al., 2002; Posch et al., 2005; Yazar et al., 2008). We report our experience of the composite ALT flap in the reconstruction of complex hand defects.

sec.title: Patients and methods
sec.p: From January 2008 to April 2010, we respectively reviewed our complex hand injury patients with more than one structural defect. There were four males and two females with age ranging from 14 to 46 years. The injury affected the left hand in five patients and the right hand in one patient. The main cause of trauma was industrial crush injury or RTA with one explosion injury (Case 2). The palm was affected by injury in three cases, the dorsum in two cases, and the radial side of the hand with amputation of the thumb in one case (Case 3). The first web space was injured in three cases. Two patients were treated primarily during the first 24 hours after trauma, three patients presented 3 weeks after trauma so they were treated in a delayed primary manner, while one case presented with severe contracture 5 months after trauma (Case 4). There was flexor tendon and nerve injury in three cases. Extensor tendons were affected in two cases, with loss of carpal and metacarpal bones in one of them (Case 4). In all cases, an ALT flap with different components was harvested and used for reconstruction. The dimensions of the flaps ranged from 6 to 10 cm in width and 11 to 22 cm in length. The fascia lata was included in the flap to provide a tendon gliding surface in four cases. Part of the vastus lateralis muscle was included to obliterate the dead space in the first web in one case (Case 6) and to create a first web space following pollicisation of the index finger in another case (Case 3). Bone block from the iliac crest was included in one flap to reconstruct the lost metacarpals (Case 4). The donor site was closed primarily in five cases and with a skin graft in one case. To assess hand function we used the DASH score with follow-up from 7 to 14 months (average 10.5 months).

sec.title: Surgical techniques
sec.p: The ALT flap was harvested in the standard fashion but when fascia lata was required, subcutaneous suprafascial dissection was carried out through the lateral incision of the flap until the desired width of fascia is dissected and then harvested. This fascia was then inserted under the reconstructed tendons and/or nerves in cases where reconstruction of such structures was required. When vascularized iliac crest was required the tensor fascia lata (TFL) was dissected upwards towards the bone. Periosteal connection of TFL to the iliac crest should be preserved to provide vascularity to the bone. The bone was reflected downwards with the TFL.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In five patients the flaps survived with complete soft tissue healing. In one case infection and subsequent partial flap necrosis developed. This healed by dressing and skin graft. One case required flap debulking. In the patient with vascularized iliac bone, bone healing occurred in 8 weeks (Figure 2e). The mean value of the DASH scores during early follow-up was 72.4 ± 5.7 (range 63.4–79.0) while the value during late follow-up was 19.17 ± 8.24 (range 10.4–34.0), showing significant improvement in the hand function.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: High-energy hand trauma frequently causes more than just skin loss and is commonly associated with muscle, nerve, bone and tendon injuries, and with vascular compromise (Giessler et al., 2003; Wood, 1997). Reconstruction of such extensive defects is usually accomplished through multiple stages, with primary skin cover by vascularized flaps followed by or combined with reconstruction of the deep structures (Scheker et al., 1993; Tropet et al., 1995; Wood, 1997). An alternative is the use of composite flaps that include multiple different vascularized tissue units in addition to the skin component. Several composite flaps have been described such as the dorsalis pedis (Caroli et al., 1993), lateral arm (Hou and Liu, 1993; Katsaros et al., 1984), fibula (Momeni and Stark, 2006), and scapular (Masaki et al., 2000) flaps.

Our work supports the work of others (Adani et al., 2006; Chen et al., 1999; Kimura et al., 2008; Muneuchi et al., 2002; Yazar et al., 2008) regarding the reliability of ALT flaps in hand reconstruction.

The ALT flap has previously been described with fascia lata to provide a gliding surface (Muneuchi et al., 2002; Yazar et al., 2008). In this work the ALT flap with vascularized fascia lata wrapping around tendon and/or nerve grafts was used in four patients over both dorsal and volar hand surfaces.

Osseo-cutaneous flaps have been used for metacarpal reconstruction (Katsaros et al., 1984; Masaki et al., 2000; Momeni and Stark, 2006). But we report using the iliac crest harvested as a vascularized bone graft as a chimeric component of the ALT flap vascularized by periosteal attachments of the TFL. This bone segment was useful for multiple metacarpal reconstruction.

Muscle flaps covered by skin graft have been used to cover hand defects and to obliterate dead spaces left after trauma. The ALT flap with a wide skin paddle for coverage and partial vastus lateralis muscle for obliteration of dead space (Posch et al., 2005) was used in our cases. Although primary thinning of the flap is possible (Adani et al., 2006), we did not do that except in one patient who had very thick subcutaneous fat.

In conclusion, the ability to use different tissue components based on individual perforators with a large calibre main source vessel allows the ALT flap to be a reliable and flexible composite flap in reconstruction of complex hand injuries.
